title: Can I write n' for and? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, you can. Strictly it’s ’n’, as letters are omitted front and back, but one or both apostrophes are often omitted. It’s extremely informal, or represents an informal and somewhat careless style of speech, so is only used occasionally. It occurs in phrases like “rock-n-roll”, also “Fish ’n’ Chips” (sometimes used in takeaway restaurant signs). It can also be used in dialogue to denote careless speech: “What are you doing?”, I asked; He shrugged, “This ’n’ that”.
